column5: however

column2: the old man's body was found

column5: and the search was eventually called off. A young boy

column10: he chanced upon what appeared to be the old man's head
column11: resting on top of a bamboo pole. The boy
column13: ran back to his people crying
column14: "Olo nin apo! Olo nin apo!" ("head of the elder" in Sambal; translates as "ulo ng apo" in Tagalog)
column15: running hysterically from house to house and village to village. The phrase stuck
column18: is how the area got its name

column1: Britain ruled the Philippines for a short time
column2: from 1762 to 1764. The British invasion of the Philippines was the first challenge to Spain's control of the archipelago after 191 years of rule. The Royal Navy and British Army joined with the East India Company in Madras to capture Spain's Asian colony. In conjunction with the attack against Spain's key possession in the Americas
column4: both settlements were successfully seized. However
column5: in the Philippines
column6: whilst the expedition was launched as part of a plan to harass the Spaniards in their possessions
column7: as well as for commercial gain and new territories
column8: the military campaign led by General William Draper and Admiral Samuel Cornish
column9: may have been launched under the guise of an invasion in order to gain prize money. The publication "When Britain Ruled the Philippines 1762–1764" describes the events as they unfolded at the Admiralty in London and at the East India Company in Madras
column10: leading to the invasion and occupation of the capital city of Manila and the port city of Cavite. The capital was looted
column12: and the British commanders imposed a ransom of four million dollars upon the Spaniards. The enormous sums in prize money and valuables seized mainly benefited the commanders.

column2: a Spanish military expedition was dispatched to study the possibility of relocating the Cavite Naval Station in Subic Bay due to its unhealthy condition.

column1: Spanish King Alfonso XII through a Royal Decree made Subic Bay (then called Subig) as Spain's stronghold in the Far East in 1884. Vice Admiral Juan Bautista de Antiquiera made Olongapo a settlement for the Spanish Navy.

column3: the Spanish Naval commission authorized construction of the Arsenal in Olongapo. The Spanish planned to make their naval station
column4: and the village of Olongapo an island
column5: protected against attack by rebels. The Spanish Navy Yard occupied the entire area east of the Spanish Gate. Employing Filipino labor
column6: they did extensive dredging of the harbor and the inner basin and built a drainage canal.  The canal served both to drain the swampy area around the yard and also to form a line of defense.

column2: the Spaniards had erected walls and markers to fence off the arsenal. They had shops and buildings erected. The Spanish government spent almost three decades developing the naval station. From higher naval commands
column3: the order was sent to fortify Grande Island at the mouth of Subic Bay with mines and cannons. But this project was hardly begun before it was overtaken by the rout of the Spanish Navy in Manila Bay by US Admiral George Dewey.
the construction of the Spanish Administration Building was hardly completed when Admiral Dewey's flagship
column4: USS Olympia
column5: led the Asiatic Fleet into Manila Bay. A detachment of Admiral Dewey's fleet bombarded the navy yard.  Eventually
column7: Spain relinquished all her rights in the Philippines to the United States.  This marked the end of more than three hundred years of Spanish rule over the islands.

column1: Realizing the tremendous importance of Olongapo as a naval facility
column2: the U.S. Navy decided to keep the base in functioning order; the President of the United States
column4: on November 9
column7: reserved the waters of Subic and some of the adjacent lands for naval purposes.

column1: The naval station was widened and with the establishment of the American rule in the Philippines. American defenses in the islands were facilities left by the Spanish Navy which were taken over by the United States.
Olongapo grew in direct proportion to the growth of the naval station.  More people came to live in Olongapo since the Navy offered employment.  To most Filipinos during that time
column2: it was a welcome change.  The promise of a different kind of experience as shop workers and office help induced many young men to leave their farms and fishing boats to work in the Navy Yard.  Others finding the lure of the sea irresistible joined the U.S. Navy.

column1: Olongapo impressed its visitors as being one of the finest communities in the country. People passing through the town never failed to comment on its cleanliness and orderliness.
When the war broke out in 1941
column2: the old town was obliterated.  Olongapo had to suffer the brunt of destruction twice.

column3: Japanese bombers attacked the Olongapo/Subic Bay area. Ten days later
column4: the order was given to burn Subic Bay Naval Station and withdraw.  Olongapo was set aflame by the local Filipinos in anticipation of Japanese troop arrival.  The USS New York was scuttled in Subic Bay. When the American forces made a last-ditch stand on the Bataan peninsula
column5: the Naval Station was abandoned and most of its facilities were burned before the Japanese came.

column2: Olongapo was again bombed
column3: shelled and burned. Joint American and Philippine Commonwealth ground troops aided the recognized guerrilla fighters in liberating Olongapo from the Japanese forces. With the exceptions of the Station Chapel (it was the Olongapo Parish Church before the war) and the Spanish Gate
column4: none of its former landmarks withstood the sweep of the war's fury. The general headquarters between the United States Army
column5: Philippine Commonwealth Army & Philippine Constabulary was stationed in Olongapo during and aftermath in World War II and active on 1945 to 1946 were operated against the Japanese for the liberation in Central Luzon.

column1: Shortly after the war was over
column2: the Philippines was granted independence.  Olongapo was one of the principal navy bases retained by the US. The Navy started to rebuild the town after the hostilities ceased. Olongapo was built on a new undeveloped site a couple of miles north of its former location.  The prewar town site became a part of the Naval Station.

column1: The first few years after the war were difficult for the new town
column2: as everything in the new Olongapo was in a deplorable state.  There was no electric power and no drainage system.  The water supply and sanitation facilities were inadequate
column4: Olongapo evolved into a better community:  new businesses were established; housing projects were planned
column5: civic facilities were restored.

column2: the US spent over $170 million to convert the base into the homeport of her Navy's Seventh Fleet
column3: developing the Cubi Naval Air Station as the largest US installation of its kind in Asia. Naval authorities relocated the residence from the area of the former Public Works Center area to what is now the hub of Olongapo – along what is now known as Rizal Avenue and Ramon Magsaysay Drive
column4: and in the Barangays New Asinan and New Kalalake areas. Zoning of Olongapo was patterned after American practice where streets are constructed along straight lines. column1: Unlike the rest of the Philippines which gained independence from the United States after World War II in 1946
column2: Olongapo was governed as a part of the United States naval reservation.  The Subic Bay Naval Base commanding officer was chairman of the Olongapo town council
column4: and hospital board.  Olongapo's 60

column6: Manila mayor Arsenio Lacson announced that US service personnel accused of crimes in Manila would be tried in Philippine courts because of US Navy abuses of Filipinos in Olongapo.  On October 23

column1: Situated at the Southern entry point of Zambales and the Northwestern interior of the Subic Bay area
column2: Olongapo City is 126 kilometres (78 mi) north of Manila.

column1: The land area of Olongapo City is 103.3 square kilometres (39.9 sq mi). The city proper is located on a 6.48 square kilometres (2.50 sq mi) tidal flatland
column2: with the rugged Zambales Mountains on its three sides
column3: and the Bataan and Subic Bay at its base. Because of this peculiar geographic location
column4: development of city land is limited. Also
column5: the territorial borders from nearby towns are not properly marked.

column1: Olongapo has a tropical monsoon climate (Köppen climate classification: Am). Temperatures are relatively cooler during the months of December
column2: January and February
column3: and increase slightly from March to May
column4: which are the warmest months of the year in this part of the Philippines.

column1: The ten Roman Catholic Parishes of Olongapo City is grouped as the Vicariate of San Jose and is under the Roman Catholic Diocese of Iba. The Parishes are namely:

St. Columban Parish (1963) in Barangay New Asinan
Santa Rita Parish (1967) in Barangay Santa Rita
Holy Trinity Parish (1975) in Barangay New Cabalan
St. Anne Parish (1985) in Brgy Gordon Heights
Immaculate Conception Parish (1986) in Barangay Barretto
San Lorenzo Ruiz Parish (1991) in Barangay New Kalalake
Holy Family Parish (1992) in Barangay Kalaklan
St. Vincent de Paul Quasi-Parish in Barangay Old Cabalan
San Roque Quasi-Parish in the Subic Bay Freeport Zone.

Both the Mayor and the ten (10) City Councilors are elected directly by the people through an election which is being held every three (3) years.

column1: As an Independent City from the province of Zambales

The City Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office (known as Olongapo City DRRMO0 are government agency which umbrella to the City Government and National Government such as National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (NDRRMC)
column2: Department of National Defense (DND) and Department of Interior and Local Government (DILG). This Agency have its well trained Rescue Service
column3: have its own Fire and Rescue equipment and Emergency Response Service for any kind of disasters. it has a capability that they adopt from the American servicemen from the Former US Naval Base. the DRRMO are separated from Olongapo City Fire Station (OCFS) under the Bureau of Fire Protection (DILG-BFP) with its same capability usual to other Fire Services. the City have its Barangay Fire Services from some Barangay's in Olongapo City that control by the Barangay Government. usually
column4: Barangay Fire Service was use as first responder in their respective territory and nearby areas. another Fire and Rescue Service was from the nearest Subic Bay Freeport Zone under its own Fire Department controlled by Subic Bay Metropolitan Authority with finest trained personnel and Rescue Equipment abandoned by the Americans similar to DRRMO. the Philippines Oldest Fire Truck was there and they also respond to the major notable disaster such as Mount Pinatubo Eruption in 1991
column5: Fukushima disaster cleanup in 2011 and Typhoon Haiyan Search and Rescue operations in 2013.

column1: The City have its 6 different Police Stations under Control by Olongapo City Police Office (OCPO) and was umbrella to Philippine National Police (PNP). the city police main garrison was on Camp Cabal (also known in locals as "164") at Barangay Barretto. another was the Law Enforcement Department controlled by the Subic Bay Metropolitan Authority which securing the coastal waters of Subic Bay and its nearby Freeport Zone under Republic Act 7227 (it is known as "SBMA Police").
The Subic Bay International Airport serves the immediate area of the Subic Bay Freeport Zone and the general area of Olongapo City (it is located in the adjacent town of Morong
column2: Bataan). This airport was once the Naval Air Station Cubi Point. The terminal has two gates. It has been proposed to be converted into a logistics hub. Currently the south-west ramp is used by US Armed Forces as part of the Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement between the Philippines and the US.

column1: The Port is operated and managed by the Subic Bay Metropolitan Authority (SBMA). It covers the fenced area of the former U.S. Naval Base Subic Bay located in the south-west of Luzon Island in the Philippines surrounded by the municipality of Subic and Olongapo City in Zambales

column1: The city has an organized road network
column2: featuring a series of rectangular street grids. The primary road that connects Olongapo to the rest of the other is the Jose Abad Santos Avenue. In the city's main district
column3: the names of those streets running from North to South follow the English alphabet's order. While streets running East to West are numbered from 1st to 27th
column4: starting from the South parallel and up. Even streets are on the East side of the city while the Odd streets are on the West. Most of the roads in Olongapo are made of concrete and asphalt.

column1: The city boasts its Color-coded Public Transportation System which it has pioneered in the country. All public utility jeepneys and tricycles have its own color code depending on the district
column2: zone or route that it is serving. It is also used for the computation of fares. For tricycles
column3: fares will differ depending on your zone of origin and destination. For jeepneys
column4: fares increases on every kilometer after the first three kilometers of the route
column5: with an exception on yellow jeepneys
column6: which has a fixed fare end-to-end. The minimum fare for tricycles are Php 7.50 per person

column1: Taxi services are also operated in the city but are limited. The taxis are not metered but have fixed rates depending on your origin and destination and they are generally used by tourists and residents alike for commuting inside the Subic Bay Freeport Zone.

Victory Liner and Saulog Transit are the leading bus operators having their own terminals in the city which transports people in and out of the city. Local bus terminals are also present and are primarily used for transportation in neighboring towns and inside the Subic Bay Freeport Zone.

column3: and the rest of the towns in Zambales up to Pangasinan province. Another access to the city is via SCTEX and Subic–Tipo Expressway exiting to the gates of Subic Bay Freeport Zone and also
column4: from the south

column7: Bataan) through the Morong gate of Subic Bay Freeport Zone.

column1: Electricity services were formerly provided by the government-run Public Utilities Department (PUD) since the city was founded. However
column2: in the late 2000s
column3: the city faced debt in its electricity distribution costs amounting to P5 billion to power suppliers and threatened to cut the city from the Luzon power grid. Then Mayor James Gordon Jr. also attributed the crisis to low collection rate due to nonpayment or debts incurred by consumers
column4: widespread energy theft and corruption in the PUD. The situation worsened because of interests imposed by Private Sector Assets and Liabilities Management Corp. (PSALM)
column5: the refusal of the Energy Regulatory Commission (ERC) to grant an increase in power rates
column6: and the years of delay in the PUD's privatization.In 2013
column8: the PUD was sold for Php 610 million to Olongapo Electricity Distribution Company (OEDC)
column9: an affiliate of Cagayan Electric Power and Light Company (CEPALCO)
column10: which was given a 25-year franchise to take over the city's power distributor. The company has since upgraded the city's obsolete and dilapidated distribution network and has made significant improvements to the city's electricity services.

column5: this was reversed and the city has bought back its shares because the city wanted to have a representation in Subic Water because the city's constituents accounted for the majority of Subic Water's customers.
